t: Proverbs 17
Better*pn is*i a dry morsel with quietness, Than*ld a house full of feasting with*i strife.
A*ln wise servant will rule over a son who causes shame, And*ld will share an inheritance among the brothers.
The*ln refining pot is*i for silver and the furnace for gold, But*ld the Lord*s tests the hearts.
An*ln evildoer gives heed to false lips; A*ld liar listens eagerly to a spiteful tongue.
He*ln who mocks the poor reproaches his Maker; He*ld who is glad at calamity will not go unpunished.
Childrenâ€™s*ln children are*i the crown of old men, And*ld the glory of children is*i their father.
Excellent*ld speech is not becoming to a fool, Much*ld less lying lips to a prince.
A*ln present is*i a precious stone in the eyes of its possessor; Wherever*ld he turns, he prospers.
He*ln who covers a transgression seeks love, But*ld he who repeats a matter separates friends.
Rebuke*ln is more effective for a wise man*i Than*ld a hundred blows on a fool.
An*ln evil man*i seeks only rebellion; Therefore*ld a cruel messenger will be sent against him.
Let*ln a man meet a bear robbed of her cubs, Rather*ld than a fool in his folly.
Whoever*ln rewards evil for good, Evil*ld will not depart from his house.
The*ln beginning of strife is*i like*i releasing water; Therefore*ld stop contention before a quarrel starts.
He*ln who justifies the wicked, and he who condemns the just, Both*ld of them alike are*i an abomination to the Lord.*s
Why*ln is*i there*i in the hand of a fool the purchase price of wisdom, Since*ld he*i has*i no heart for*i it?*i
A*ln friend loves at all times, And*ld a brother is born for adversity.
A*ln man devoid of understanding shakes hands in a pledge, And*ild becomes surety for his friend.
He*ln who loves transgression loves strife, And*ld he who exalts his gate seeks destruction.
He*ln who has a deceitful heart finds no good, And*ld he who has a perverse tongue falls into evil.
He*ln who begets a scoffer does*i so*i to his sorrow, And*ld the father of a fool has no joy.
A*ln merry heart does good, like*i medicine, But*ld a broken spirit dries the bones.
A*ln wicked man*i accepts a bribe behind the back To*ld pervert the ways of justice.
Wisdom*ln is*i in the sight of him who has understanding, But*ld the eyes of a fool are*i on the ends of the earth.
A*ln foolish son is*i a grief to his father, And*ld bitterness to her who bore him.
Also,*ln to punish the righteous is*i not good, Nor*ild to strike princes for their*i uprightness.
He*ln who has knowledge spares his words, And*ild a man of understanding is of a calm spirit.
Even*ln a fool is counted wise when he holds his peace; When*ild he shuts his lips, he*i is*i considered*i perceptive.
